review_title: Thumbtack is such an amazing place to work!
pros:
I have so many pros when thinking about my experience so far at Thumbtack. Below are a few that stand out when I reflect on my time here:
- A collaborative, open-minded culture
- Humble, intelligent, and kind coworkers
- Meaningful work -- an opportunity to help small businesses grow and solve super complex yet interesting challenges
- An incredible culinary team that prepares amazing food and meals for Thumbtack employees
- A good work / life balance
- Transparent management
cons: No 401k matching offered at the moment and more people need to know about and use Thumbtack! Overall, I have so many pros when thinking about my time at this company and so very few cons -- it is an incredible place to work!

pros: Working at Thumbtack it's really lovely to be surrounded by passionate people who genuinely like what they do. If you do not have a passion for helping others, or you do not see yourself in a position to accept and openly offer criticism, you will not grow here. If you work hard and actively propel yourself you will love working at Thumbtack.
cons: Some of Thumbtack's values, while for the most part are positive can have a tendency to run faster than what they can keep up with. They are constantly trying to change to improve and it's invaluable in the technology industry but can be frustrating if ideals have been implemented, yet they are already working on the next before they've mastered the recent.
advice_to_mgmt: It's okay to slow down a little. #Go shouldn't just mean run, run, run. It should also account for improvement on current ideas and people.

pros: Awesome culture, seriously I have never had so much fun at a job before. The actual job itself is pretty standard to a call center job, however, it doesn't feel that way because of how many fun things are going on at Thumbtack. There is a very open feel, as there are no cubicles, couches to sit on, weekly meetings with leadership, that makes you feel like you are included in the process. You get catered lunches Mon-Fri which save a ton of money especially since they are great caterers that make the food fresh every day, kombucha on tap, and tons of snacks to munch on. There is a gym to use, and tons of events to break up the monotony of the work week. Culture is everything here! Oh and you get "Thumbtack bucks" to use quarterly which can save you a lot of money on your personal projects you'd use the site for on your own.
cons: Constant changes with teams and the product itself, this can be good or bad depending on how you like a changing environment. For me I don't mind but I know some people have a hard time with it. There is not as much room for growth as I would like, it seems a lot of people when they get to where I am at have left for other companies after applying for multiple positions here and not getting them. There has been talk of getting a bonus structure built out for quite a while, but nothing put in place yet and it's been over a year. Honestly, I love the culture but other jobs do seem tempting that have a more competitive compensation for similar roles.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't mention a bonus structure until it is ready to actually be put into place. It leads to disappointment when one isn't built out when you thought it was going to be. I love the culture though and keep up the good work with making things so fun at work! It's what keeps me wanting to go in every day which is rare for a "call center" type of job.

And people there are friendly.

Because say, if you get $50 per user, it is likely that those pros on Thumbtack will ask a price $60 higher than craigslist. And in turn, users will leave thumbtack.

review_title: There are some issues with the cultures that go unnoticed from the inside
pros:
- I'm normally not really a big fan of the free food perk, but at Thumbtack, the culinary team really outdoes itself compare to the other companies.
- The company makes an effort to be respectful towards LGBT employees.
- You realize how much impact you have when you look at the changing lives of independent professionals who use Thumbtack.
cons:
- Remember that awkward scene in the movie "Social Network", where Zuckerberg wears his headphone on, and nobody is allowed to approach him because he's in "the zone". Well someone at Thumbtack thought it was cool and turned that into a policy. Now it becomes the norm to have to message the coworker sitting right next to you to ask a question, because they wear their headphones on.
- At some point, someone pointed out that employees should clean after themselves and not leave their mugs behind. Nothing wrong with that, but suddenly several employees started jumping the bandwagon, then we'd regularly see some public shaming on Slack, with attached pictures of unattended mugs. To me that's just weird.
advice_to_mgmt: - Pay attention to what's happening to the culture.

pros: Thumbtack offers a lot of perks and benefits, including a generous PTO policy, laptops for work and personal use, free lunches, tons of snacks, coffee machines, fun company events, etc. The company vision is something that I believed in from day one, and still do. They want small businesses to grow and succeed. It shows, especially when you visit the San Francisco office. There's a lot of energy behind that vision.
cons:
In the Salt Lake office, the culture was once laid-back, fun, and amazing. At the time I started working there, it was hands-down the best place to work in Utah. People were promoted based on hard work and drive. Employees constantly went above and beyond because at that time, you were recognized for doing so.

Now, however, the Salt Lake office has become riddled with political agendas and favoritism. Managers that were once friendly with their employees became bosses, pushing numbers instead of empowering people. People get promoted based on their friendships outside of work with their managers, rather than their actual achievements. (For example: The people who go out drinking with the boss are the ones that get the most attention, rather than the ones that keep their heads down.) You can have the exact same metrics as someone else, but they'll get promoted over you because they're sucking up and you're not. This never, EVER used to be allowed at Thumbtack (most managers would be annoyed with the teacher's pet kind of employee), but now it's the norm.

Many departments are weighed down by stressful goals and ridiculous, impossible performance plans that only set people up to fail. There are multiple managers in multiple departments that aren't people leaders and don't know how to be. Those managers in particular are a HUGE part of what has destroyed the culture and have pushed people to their limit.

Surprisingly for a company that's growing rapidly, there's little to no opportunity for growth in many departments there. The only hope you have for moving up is starting in customer support. However, once you're out of that department, good luck going anywhere else.

The Salt Lake office is also riddled with HR red flags, but it's virtually impossible to go to HR without getting in trouble for it. Multiple managers and "star" employees are walking HR violations, but continue to be rewarded rather than punished for their behavior.

Overall, Thumbtack WAS an amazing place to work but now the culture is stressful, toxic, and severely overrated.
advice_to_mgmt: Management needs to go back to treating people like people rather than numbers. The culture has wilted and died because of managers who don't stand up for the best interest of their employees and ultimately let them fail.

review_title: Without a doubt the best place I've ever worked at.
pros:
-Inclusive Culture

The culture here is excellent, it really feels like family when coming here, which is a good thing since we spend most of our days with our co-workers. Cross department communication is great as well.

-Room for Growth

Internal mobility is encouraged here, as well as opportunities to be a mentor or mentee with another Thumbtacker.

-Seamless Onboarding

This really gets started about a week before you get here, you get to pick your own equipment and desk setup before you even get here. When you do get here all of your stuff is ready to go at your desk, including a sweet little welcome package. Extended onboarding includes Thumbtack University which is a multi-day training session that goes over the company and its history. The product’s evolution and current state, and some research methods and options within Thumbtack.

-Food

The food here is ridiculously good. Food here is cooked in house by some of the most amazing chefs. You’ll be enjoying daily breakfast, lunch, and dinner (except Fridays). Also with Thursday snack days you’ll be treated to an assortment of in house snacks and beverages. Speaking of beverages there are ‘coolers’ or ‘refreshers’ made in house, a personal favorite is the Passion Fruit cooler. We also have a few beers and wines on tap, and in cans/bottles if you don’t like those options. There’s even an instagram account dedicated to this talented crews’ work.

-Extremely flexible with PTO

Need time off? Take it.

-Transparency

Meeting notes are dispersed across departments which provides a window on what the company is working on. This goes all the way to the top.

-Thoughtful and Hands on Leadership

Leadership here is astoundingly great and active! They’re quick to respond to major events and set a great atmosphere for the company as a whole. They listen to feedback

-Offsite Team Building Events

Want to get to know your team better? Don’t worry you’ll have a lot of opportunities to get out of the office with your team and build that relationship up!

-On-site Guest Speaker Events

Thumbtack is increasing their efforts in being thought leaders and having more community based events.

-Community Involvement

Thumbtackers respond to help out our local community, especially when they need it most like our most recent fires. We also have a few internal groups for different sports and activities that take place outside of work hours.

-SF Office Space / Location

We’re in the Twitter building which is pretty convenient for most people living in the city, and pretty close to most transportation options.
cons: It's hard to write something here without sounding pretentious and entitled. I don't have any complaints.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing, it's amazing and I'm excited to see where this goes!

On top of that, Thumbtack is taking its thriving marketplace and taking a huge swing at a radically improved experience for local services. Trust me when I say this is a once in a lifetime work opportunity.

I would happily recommend Thumbtack to any great employee who wants to love their work and make a huge difference.
cons: Building something new and different is not easy. If you are not comfortable with ambiguity and moving quickly, you will likely find yourself unhappy at Thumbtack in its current stage.
advice_to_mgmt: Let's continue to be bold and push hard towards our vision

review_title: Not the best place to work for anymore :(
pros:
- great perks like free lunches, stocked kitchen, events
- great benefits
- open space environment
cons:
- the culture used to be top-notch, now that the company has grown a lot and still keeps growing, the culture is slipping away. I've read other reviews about Thumbtack too especially the negative ones and they're all on point. They say that they're not micromanaging you but the truth is they are. They use positive-scripting to "keep the culture" but they're not really doing a great job.
- when it comes to promotion, it's also who you know and not what you know.
- people that are personally struggling don't get much support from the management and the company although that WAS their intention. It used to be an employee-centered company too, but now they're just about numbers and how to make the company bigger.
- I used to brag about Thumbtack but now I would not even recommend it to anyone anymore because of all the changes
- not much career growth. They used to say that since it's a start-up company, there are tons of growth opportunity, everything has been filled in I guess so you're staying where you're at now.
advice_to_mgmt: After working here for 3 years, I've seen the ups and downs and all the changes that the company has done. Listen to your employees, value them, show them how much you appreciate them. Care for them, support them, and understand them when they have personal struggles, everyone is different. Be genuine about things that you tell your employees. Motivate them to work harder when they're struggling instead of putting pressure on them.

advice_to_mgmt: Not much really. The company is very well managed. I just didn't like working at a call center. Even if it was for a very exciting company. I'm not sure if it makes sense strategically, but I would love to see some proper engineering, analyst, management jobs in Utah.

review_title: Smart people, super exciting mission, great culture
pros:

- Huge market and vision for the company: no lack of desire to change the world

cons: - Tons of growth and change can be somewhat chaotic and hard to keep up

review_title: Amazing growth, business problems, and team
pros:
I've personally grown much faster than I expected. I've learned as much about software engineering as I have about product decision-making, analytics, and project management—all as a new-grad hire.

Almost everyone here is exceptionally helpful and cooperative. The company is intensely mission-driven and people are well-aligned with the company's vision.

People here are smart. With few exceptions, I am impressed by the caliber of team members here and the lengths they go to not only understand our customers, product, and market.

There is immense company growth potential. We are years ahead of even our biggest competitors in a market that, in the US alone, is worth $700 billion annually. There are few other tech companies that can even claim to have that much potential for growth—let alone a strong chance at realizing that potential.

Upper management is excellent. I rarely question the decisions made by executives about our team and our product because they are accessible, transparent about their reasoning, and deeply concerned with data-driven decision-making. At the same time, they seem to balance these traits with well-honed intuitions about how to make step changes in the product that take us in the right direction.
cons:
While the company has been receptive to feedback about career growth, it still has room for improvement. I realize catering to people's career growth needs is often in tension with team agility and bureaucracy minimization, but I think Thumbtack is capable of finding a better balance.

Given our ambitions, we need to grow our team more quickly than we currently are, without resorting to the pell-mell of hiring that was 2016. I think a crucial part of this will be polishing our brand and doing better at publicizing the great work we're doing here.
advice_to_mgmt: Trust your team members to take initiative, give them space to own their work, and be a source of context and assistance.

review_title: The outside is appealing, that's how they get you
pros:
Free food.
Decent working hours.
Specific teams aren't bad.
The benefits are great.
cons:
Faking it completely. The CEO came to Salt Lake to deliver news and decided to plant people in the audience to say kind things about the updates to shape the narrative. If that isn't shady, I don't know what is.
The politicking is insane.
The "culture" isn't diverse. Hiring the same type of people doesn't get you new ideas or thinking outside of the box. Getting actually diversity in people instead of who they voted for would do you good. It's a fancy call center for lazy hipsters.
The CEO and leadership think they are bigger than they are and walk around with their noses in the air. They company is still growing and it's a good time to be humble.
There wasn't an HR until the last year or so. Lots of issues brewing that aren't being solved. People get promoted to leadership because of who they know, not because of their work ethic. Overpaid management and underpaid staff.
Management who used to be in HR actually sexually harassed employees without any repercussions even with ALL of senior leadership knowing about it.
Firing managers, senior leaderships, and VPs is seen as a weakness so they will keep people around who are clearly unqualified just to save face.
Being a "cool place to work" invites inappropriate behavior that is brushed off as being "fun" or "hip" yet they push unbias training down everyones throat and make it mandatory that you show up. It's not helpful and all it does is push people who were already afraid of speaking up further into their corners.
advice_to_mgmt: Take actual advice. Stop preaching "always be improving" when no one in sr. leadership in the TSL office has shown any sign of it. It's covered up with daily high fives that disrupt your work. But better for management to be seen as friendly instead of actually using "high five time" to do something meaningful. Stop it and cut the crap.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work at.
pros: Thumbtack has some amazing people still working there. You get catered lunch, free snacks, and awesome events are planned. The product Thumbtack is working on will change the services market, if they don't continue on this horrible path they are on.
cons:
Micromanagers, bosses instead of leaders, metrics that are hard to obtain, constantly being told you're paid more than you're worth, constant changes that don't make any sense.

The changes that are made on a weekly basis just anger professionals we work with and they feel like Thumbtack is just in it for the money, which is it seeming like it more and more everyday. When you bring up feedback, you think they care about it, but they don't do much to implement it. We have 2 offices, and the office in SF is not in tune with SLC, so they make changes that WE know are going to anger customers, and they are surprised when they get negative feedback.

TT used to brag about transparency and how much they valued their employees, now they only care about numbers and you can end up getting fired in a matter of weeks because of their high metrics.

Lots of politics, if you're a brown noser, you will get special projects to work on and not have to work as hard as everyone else.

You are only important to Thumbtack as long as you are performing, if you have a tough week, you will get into a bad groove and it's hard to recover.

Some "leaders" take it upon themselves to target employees and try to get them fired for bringing up issues to upper management or hr.

The good people are realizing that it's better to leave then stay and deal with all the garbage going on so tenured employees are dropping like flies.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop bringing in people externally and hire within like before, you guys are bringing in people that only care about numbers and have no idea what our culture was like before and they don't care about the employees. Listen to the professionals and customers instead of implementing updates that just make them mad and want to stop using Thumbtack. Also give your leaders training so they know how to handle difficult situations instead of taking it out on employees and making them feel like scum. Start caring about your employees because if your employees are happy, they will take care of the customers. Stop tolerating drama, and inappropriate activity.

pros: Thumbtack has an amazing Culture, and they really value their employees.
cons: I can't think of any cons, because Thumbtack is the best company to work for.

review_title: Exceptional Culture + Exciting Vision and Potential
pros: Let's start with the easy stuff: amazing lunches and snacks served daily, great office space, excellent activities and spirit days, awesome swag. But that's really just the surface layer. If you go deeper, you find the office culture is friendly and open, nearly all members of management at all levels are motivated sincerely to help people succeed and grow, and the company values and product vision are compelling. I've worked with many different companies in varying capacities, and I've rarely seen a company with so many positives. Summary: It's an exceptional place to work, and the product has incredible potential.
cons: This may sound like I'm glossing over things, but there really aren't any major cons compared to other companies in similar spaces. Like all things, you'll get out of out what you put into it, and if your style is to hide out or get by on minimum effort, this probably won't be a good fit for you. Also, the pace Thumbtack moves (fast!) isn't for everyone.
advice_to_mgmt: I work in the Salt Lake office, and the direction this office is moving is exciting! I especially admire the commitment to transparency at all levels. The ambitious, smart, but friendly culture being created here has me feeling very optimistic about the company's future and very happy to be a part of the team.

pros:
I love coming to work here every day. We are helping real customers with important life projects while helping small businesses nationwide grow. That mission and that impact creates a really positive baseline for everyone here.

In addition, my colleagues are nearly uniformly friendly, warm, and smart. Meetings are collegial, even when there is disagreement. Hours and work-life-balance are very manageable, even when you have a family as I do. That said, the collegial atmosphere makes even these minor cons easy to work around and within. Plus the leadership team is acutely aware of the challenges that come with growth and constantly working to address them.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing, making bold bets on the future of the company while investing heavily in maintaining our culture.

pros:

• Fast paced company that is constantly growing and changing. You will hardly ever be bored.

review_title: Great if you don't work in product

Since there's a lot of build and do, you'll get the opportunity to work on ground breaking projects.
cons: No 401k matching. Worklife balance isn't great, you can expect Slack and email notifications through the night and weekend. The engineering, product, and design cultures aren't well aligned. Engineering tends to get highest precedent. The product development process is still in progress. The day to day working experience is intense because of the EPD culture of urgency and many meetings. Decision making at every stage of product is heavily dependent on committee decisions amongst product management. There is no career development framework or explicit role definition. Although the culture values transparency, management often lacks transparency. Not enough headcount.
advice_to_mgmt:
Focus on making the company the best it can be rather than comparable to Facebook or Google.
Be honest and transparent.
Listen to your staff and invest in their development.
Be respectful and thoughtful of employees that are leaving the company.

review_title: Best company I have ever worked for
pros:
The culture is fantastic. There are no egos, and pretty much everyone is willing to drop what they're doing to answer a question or to point you in the right direction. The company is built on transparency, so you know what other teams are working on and how that contributes to the larger vision of the exec team.

Everyone has an opportunity to make an impact. We're at that stage in which the user base is relatively well established, and yet is still growing rapidly. You won't be working on some widget that only a handful of people will see or use.

People come here because they believe in the product and the mission, not just to collect a paycheck.

In-house culinary team provides great food 3x a day. It is wonderful not to have to wander around SOMA every day looking for lunch.

Work-life balance is great. There is no pressure to work a minimum number of hours a day, and you have the flexibility to work from home if you have an obligation that prevents you from coming into the office. I've almost never done work after leaving the office for the day.

We're beyond the instability and uncertainty that comes with early startups, yet we've only captured a small fraction of the $700 billion local services marketplace. There's enormous room for growth and I'm confident we are moving in the right direction.
cons:
The company is growing so rapidly that sometimes there are breakdowns in communication, or teams step on each other's toes.

Understaffed in certain areas. Until recently, the mobile team was understaffed, and people with substantial front end experience are still in short supply. That's one of the major pain points in the overall dev cycle.

Greater proportion of people here (anecdotally), as compared to other companies in the Bay Area I've worked at, are married and/or have kids. So, don't expect a lot of interest if you ask people to go out for a drink or do something outside of work as they're probably making a beeline for the Caltrain station.
advice_to_mgmt:
Continue to be selective about whom to hire, not only in terms of overall competence, but also in terms how well they "fit" into the Thumbtack culture.

Continue to emphasize transparency in your communications.

Don't be afraid to take big risks and possibly fail.

pros:

This is a very creative and open work environment, with tons of hard problems and smart/fun people to work on them with. The company is in a huge growth cycle right now and so there is plenty of opportunities to make a huge impact very quickly. I've surprised myself by how much I have accomplished since coming here because of the responsibilities I've been given, and this is without anyone pushing long unnecessary hours on us!

Most importantly to me, above anything I mentioned above, is knowing that I'm building a product that is helping people carve out careers for themselves by their rules. We constantly get to hear stories from people that have created meaningful employment for themselves and others through Thumbtack and it really makes me feel like I'm doing something that matters.

Also we have an AWESOME in house kitchen that feeds us oh so well!

pros:
The two main reasons I love working at Thumbtack:

1) We're actually having an impact on the world. A lot of people use Thumbtack to fuel their small business. Some wouldn't exist without Thumbtack and some would, but just be smaller. To be able to empower people to pursue their entrepreneurial passions is really cool.

2) The people at Thumbtack are great. It's not always common to find a culture that prizes ambition, intelligence, AND kindness, but all three are definitely present among those working at Thumbtack and this makes working at Thumbtack much more enjoyable.
cons: It's scary to not be an established player like Google or Facebook. While we're doing well financially, there's no guarantee that Thumbtack will be around in 10 years. Having said that, this is also an opportunity. Everyone can make an impact at Thumbtack and leave their mark here in a way that wouldn't be possible at one of the aforementioned companies.
advice_to_mgmt: Be as aggressive as possible in getting us to where we all want to be. There's a fine line here as no one wants to burn out, but, on the other hand, people at the company will be more disappointed if we don't push ourselves enough to reach our long-term goals.

Great product! - solving a real problem that most people can relate to

review_title: Best company I've worked for yet!
pros: Culture is awesome, the people are awesome. If you work hard doors open and you get opportunities to advance. Great work life balance, you're amazing, free catered meals, awesome benefits and stock options.
cons: Sometimes people get hired on that start bringing in negativity, like complaining about little things I feel are insignificant. Good thing is we're always improving.

pros:

review_title: Thoughtful, genuine place to do your best work
pros:
- Extremely transparent, earnest culture. Founders are young but they are mature, good people and very accessible.
- Mission-driven, with great prospects.
- Smartest and most curious people you will ever work with. Work here if you like to ask why.
- Female and LGBT leaders trusted and supported in very visible, impactful roles.
- Learning emphasis. We've been getting better and better at bringing opportunities into the building.
- Very reasonable working pace and culture. It fluctuates based on project demands but you can have a real life outside of work.
- Food isn't just a perk - it is truly amazing and it brings people from different teams together.
cons:
- Agree with previous reviewer re: creating a culture of gratitude, not just featuring people at All Thumbs. People here are so nice that they don't jockey for credit - but current system is built to reward good-looking metrics, not necessarily the important things (like infrastructure or supporting team members).
- Extremely cautious, planning oriented culture. Good and bad. Helps work/life balance, feels mature and improves execution. But we could make bigger, more creative bets if we found ways to make occasional failure OK.
- Career development needs work. Titles here feel junior (vs. other companies) and can make people feel like Thumbtack doesn't believe in them (even when it does). Need to give people more chances to build new skills, not just execute their one function.
- Gender issues here are better than elsewhere, but we can still improve on unconscious bias, especially on more male teams (eng/product).
- Ditto what other reviewers have said about average comp/benefits (for tech).
advice_to_mgmt: Thanks for taking the culture here so seriously.

review_title: Great place to work full of mission-driven, intellectual people
pros:
Thumbtack is a really great company with a very strong culture and an obsessive focus on improving itself. Everyone from the engineers to the recruiters to the operations teams are approachable, curious, humble, dedicated to learning, and fun to talk with. The product makes a difference in people's lives and the opportunity is huge, which makes the environment exciting and the work satisfying. Decisions from hires to product changes to ad buys are made in a very thoughtful, rigorous manner, but bad decisions are owned up to and abandoned quickly.

Very little ego or politics within the company, as everyone seems committed to making the best decisions to help the team, and working hard to make that decision making process as analytically rigorous and free from bias as possible. As a start up there are many opportunities for team members to contribute and expand their horizons and leadership offers support for people to figure out and implement new things.

I love coming to work here.
cons: The relentlessly thoughtful decision making process means that the company can move more slowly than it perhaps should at times. Engineer hiring has proven to be a major bottleneck due to absurdly high standards for new hires. As a result, teams that could get by with less than world-class engineers are left without any engineering resources at all. Also as a result the product has simple, glaring flaws that go left unaddressed, and there are clearly areas of the company set up years ago that have been given no thought in a while as attention is focused elsewhere. Huge opportunity for new hires to fix these things and help this company realize its potential.
advice_to_mgmt: The company is incredibly transparent but somehow key decisions aren't getting communicated across teams. Resources that are largely locked within certain areas today could be made more available to others. Consider hiring more experienced staff across the board so there is a diminished need for everyone to be learning on the job at the same time. More experienced staff could also provide leadership and guidance that is somewhat lacking today.

pros:
*** TEAM ***
The people and the culture they embody make Thumbtack a truly special place to work. These adjectives describe the team:
+ Hyper intelligent
+ Friendly
+ Positive & optimistic
+ Ambitious
+ Open minded
+ Collaborative
+ Trustworthy
+ Emotionally intelligent

A lot of qualities emerge from this mix. I'm a person who tends to attract conflict. I'm loud, outspoken, and I don't react well to foul play. I can truly say that in 1 year of working here I have yet to had a single conflict with anyone here, work related or otherwise. I also haven't met one person who I really don't want to work with. For me, both of those facts really stand out.

*** VISION ***
Thumbtack has been around for quite sometime, 7 or 8 years. Throughout that time, the founders' vision has remained remarkably consistent. They also communicate it effectively. That solves a lot of problems for a growing team. We may disagree on execution, but we all share the same long term vision for the company and the product. That, combined with the attributes mentioned above, make me really feel like I'm part of a team all striving together towards the same shared goal.

*** SOCIAL GOOD ***
It's really hard for most of us to be excited about working for companies of neutral or dubious societal value. My last job was in social / F2P games so believe me, I know what I'm talking about. Working on a platform that empowers small businesses to succeed and helps customers have confidence in hiring professionals is really easy to be excited about. Every week we are treated to more stories about professionals whose lives have been changed by the ability Thumbtack gives them to pursue and succeed at their dreams.
cons:
- The salary and benefits are very average. Certainly not bad, but also not a selling point.
- Thumbtack expects a lot out of its employees. The high bar in hiring corresponds to an equally high bar in performance. This can create a climate where people feel taken for granted. If you're not shipping product that moves a key metric by 20%, you're generally not receiving much praise. Not a good place to feel insecure. If you're doing well, meeting expectations, you probably won't hear very many thank you's or good job's.
advice_to_mgmt: Recognition doesn't mean getting your name on the screen at our weekly "All-thumbs" meeting. It doesn't mean winning an award. It doesn't mean getting a #LoveIt from a co-worker. Recognition means a culture of gratitude. When I finish a project it's great to hear all of the ideas for how I could take it to the next level. But if I've produced acceptable work, don't forget the "Thank you," and "Good woork!" They make a lot of difference.

pros: Working at Thumbtack has been incredible and continues to be month after month. I recommend friends to join every chance I get. Best group of people I've ever worked with, lots of opportunity and with a work/life balance. Can't ask for better.
cons: I can't really come up with any downsides

review_title: Great vision. TSF is on point. Heavy Politics in TSL.
pros: Founders really care about affecting the world in a positive way and translate this through to their product, interactions with pros, Aand investment in employee perks. They are really stand-up guys who are concerned more about the good they do and how they affect people's lives than their bottom line.
cons:
Very heavy politics which bleed into upper management in TSL. One or two weak managers promote and keep weaker players in leadership positions because they are liked and not because of their contributions or proven skills. They tout transparency but fail to examine the facts behind complaints about management and look for anywhere (or anyone) else to point the finger to rather than holding the leaders accountable first - which could end up being a much larger downfall and problem as Thumbtack scales.

Weak and inexperienced managers are allowed to continue making the same mistakes at the cost of their direct reports productivity, career progression/security, reputation and morale and are not held accountable to any level of responsibility for their own actions or inactions.
advice_to_mgmt:
VP or Directors doing team skip-levels will help them stay directly in touch with what agents are thinking/feeling about management and other practices at the front lines and help eliminate politics as information is passed up the chain.

HR conducting and putting higher emphasis on peer and direct report reviews

 Pay attention to the pain points that come to light now as they will only grow larger and more disruptive as Thumbtack grows even larger

review_title: Strong Tech Company with Great Business Sense
pros:
Joining from a big tech company, Thumbtack has everything I’d expect for a good startup: smart people, good perks, nice food, beautiful office, no politic culture, visionary CEO. I won’t go into details on those aspects as they are mostly covered by other reviews. What really makes me excited to come to work each day is what Thumbtack differentiates from other startups.

Thumbtack is competing in a huge market (800 billions per year in US for local services)/ Like in any other big markets: search, social network or online shopping, there will eventually have one dominate player at the end. (Google for search, Facebook for social network, Amazon for online shopping). Based on the current competition status, Thumbtack has a good shot to win this game.

Tech startups live or die on growth, no doubt about that. Thumbtack focuses on making a profitable business as much as pushing impressive growth rate. We don't play games of selling 1 dollar for 70 cents to feed the growth like many other startups. The business model of Thumbtack is creative, healthy and having a great potential.
cons: I feel we are not moving fast enough on the product and engineering side. We are emphasize too much on engineering excellence. A bit of “move fast and break thing” spirit would be useful for this company at the current stage.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the good momentum and move even faster

pros:
There's a lot to like about Thumbtack.
- Employees are super intellectual while being very down to earth.
- The office is gorgeous: flooded with natural light, cozy work nooks, lots of meeting spaces, and an incredible rooftop view.
- The food is amazing. We're so spoiled with talented in-house chefs who keep us well fed for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
- We're doing very human-centric work that positively impacts so many lives—it's very cool to see.
- We're on verge of getting very big, very quickly.
cons:
But thing's aren't perfect.
- A lot of very similarly minded people—a little diversity of thought would do us good.
- Our high focus on data and conversion changes is good but comes with the danger of thwarting creativity, big-picture thinking, and risk taking.
- All those smart people who work here mean a lot of employees are doing work they're overqualified for with unclear paths for internal growth.
- Growing pains. We're still learning how to adapt our structure and process to accommodate a much larger office. There's a lot of hustle and far less attention to culture.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Don't forget to focus on culture. Hard work is an important value to nurture, but so is encouragement and affirmation. High morale will lead to easier recruiting.
- Seek out leaders, not just high-performers. A structure that encourages natural mentorship and growth is a good thing.
- Own up to the growing pains we're experiencing—accountability allows for better conversations and opportunities to improve.

pros:
-Pleasant and inspiring coworkers
-In it for the long haul to build a sustainable business, and I think we have a very good shot at succeeding
cons:
I have basically one con. We're rather image focused. This takes several forms:
-We are recruiting heavily, which means we want to appear like a good place to work. We send out multiple reminders to fill out Glassdoor reviews, write and upvote recruiting blog posts, and so on. Now, we actually happen to *be* a decent place to work. But it's a little weird to be in a place where a large part of your job is proselytizing rather than doing the things you are proselytizing about...
-Our business was built around SEO. Fortunately optimizing for SEO tends to somewhat aligned with creating value for the world. But when considering a feature, we sometimes ask "what will get Googlebot to like us more" rather than "what will make a better product for our users."
advice_to_mgmt: As the company grows, put more effort into ethical behavior -- in our past, we could be decent people without much conscious effort. But bigger companies sometimes have a harder time with that.

Marco is an amazing leader - charismatic, capable, encouraging, unbelievably calm under pressure. Super strong culture and maniacal focus on maintaining as we grow.
cons: Strong cultural focus means we hire a lot of people who are "like us"... Will need to diversify somewhat as we grow. Also have felt product was moving slowly until last few months when it has massively accelerated (and will continue to accelerate through 2016)
advice_to_mgmt: San Francisco

pros:
-Cool, fun, engaging, and friendly people
-Lots of perks, including yoga, massages, chefs, thumbtack bucks, and education reimbursement
-Impressive office with skylights, big open work spaces, couches, and places to develop friendships
-Inspiring CEO
-Growth is very exciting
-Academic environment
-They encourage transparency
cons:

-Emails are sent at all hours of the night
-Meetings are scheduled at 10pm for 9am the next morning

pros: Still MOSTLY has that startup vibe and the perks associated with it. Decent benefits and whatnot
cons: It's quickly losing the startup vibe, and wages and benefits aren't increasing to match it. It's quickly becoming more 'corporate"

pros: Everyone's really committed to excellence. The people are incredibly friendly, intelligent, and reasonable. Management structure is very flat and highly transparent. The company's mission, to make it easier for small businesses to connect to prospective customers, is very motivating. The food is phenomenal! The working environment is quirky and fun. IT staff is excellent and responsive. I haven't had a negative experience with a single employee. I enjoy coming to work! Terrific benefits and a flexible hours, unlimited PTO policy ensures people stay healthy and rested. I think this company has a tremendous future ahead of it, and I'm happy to be a part of it.
cons: I live in mid-Peninsula and the commute is a bit longer for me, but I can use the exercise. It's a nice half-hour walk from Caltrain, and only four blocks to BART.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up.

pros: EXCELLENT benefits. Insurance, 401k, tuition reimbursement, free catered lunch (really high quality food), free snacks, quality/variety of coffee. Wonderful people for the most part to work with. Company does really great things, listens to feedback and implements good things for customers, professionals and employees.
cons: Expectations are HIGH, stressfully so. Management tries to keep benefits outweighing downsides, but I'm aware of several people who have left company for stress related health problems. Can be hard to keep up a high standard of quality work when it's extremely fast paced. Company is also very clique-ish, it's normal for people to have their groups, but it's extremely divided and is noticeable because it's touted that company is "not" clique-y. Social aspect of work is extremely important to managers, and it can be hard if you don't fit in - just like high school.
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure to keep up great work and continue listening to feedback. Promote based on merit rather than social standing.

pros: Because of their high hiring bar they've built a kickass team of smart, talented and awesome people. Great culture, perks and beautiful office. There's a great opportunity for this company to soar.
cons: Lack of urgency with product changes and updates. The product still has a long way to go and we need to act fast.

pros: Thumbtack is going places. It's inspiring to work with such talented, motivated, and humble people. This is a company that holds true to its values.
cons: There have been some questionable leadership changes recently. There are also very real growing pains which are slowly but surely being addressed.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't get too tied up in politics. Other leaders' agendas shouldn't take priority over the best interest of entire teams.

pros: Thumbtack has a warm, friendly culture, great food, great product. Overall, it's been great to work here!
cons: We're growing really fast, and there are some growing pains associated with this growth.

review_title: Generous Company But Lacking Solid Decision-Making Skills
pros: The founders are humble. The culture and values are good. They kinda care about their workers. They're generous most of the time.
cons: They lack decision-making skills. Once they've raised the salary to beyond what is commonly offered and everyone was motivated. All of a sudden, they dropped it real low and ended a number of contracts without prior notice. Also, their QA department is very uncalibrated and their members are too proud of themselves.

pros: Room for growth and improvement. The company really seems to care about its employees well being. It was a great place to work with some great people. Someone was always willing to help if you just asked. I would recommend doing your research on the company before applying.
cons: I wouldn't say there too many cons. At the end of the day it's a business that is trying to grow its bottom line. In order to keep the doors open management must make some decisions

pros: Thumbtack recognizes talent and potential. They give you opportunities to grow as a professional and to handle bigger things as long as you're up for it.
cons: There are still many improvements that need to be done to the product itself, and we need more engineers to make that happen.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue making the working environment great by focusing on culture yet putting more pressure on engineering enhancements.

pros: My coworkers are engaged and thoughtful. The company does what they can to make it a great place to work. Information is freely shared. I enjoy coming to work everyday. Free lunch.

pros: Some co-workers are AWESOME!, Macbooks, tons of free food, tons of PTO

pros:

pros: "Humble, but ambitious" is a great encapsulation of the tremendous culture here at Thumbtack. The opposite is true here at Thumbtack, where I'm surrounded by really impressive but approachable folks all working together towards a really meaningful goal.
cons: The only con I can think of is that our tendency to "reason from first principles" means we can sometimes be slow to execute. I think on balance this is a good thing, but sometimes we take it a bit far and lose out on chances to learn & iterate at a faster prace.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay focused on the customer and the rest will follow.

pros:
Amazing opportunity for growth and to share ideas.
The people are genuinely happy and glad to be at work.
Free FOOD!
cons: They are always improving. There is a suggestion box as well as open forums to share ideas for improving.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay amazing through the growth.

pros: They legitimately care about their employees. We see a lot of the CEO and President who fly out to keep in touch. They even take phone calls when they come out, so they really know exactly what the agents on the ground are dealing with. Our benefits are awesome and the culture is phenomenal.
cons: It's really cramped in the office, but we're building a new office. Just growing pains. For now there's a lot of desk sharing and a lot of pressure to work from home, but that will go away when we move into our new building next spring.
advice_to_mgmt: You guys are killing it, just make sure not to let people get lost in the shuffle as we grow.

review_title: Great place with a bit of drama
pros: Thumbtack is great! If you like a place that is always changing and challenging you to become better this is the place for you! If you don't like numbers and pushing to the next level I would keep looking .

advice_to_mgmt: Stop dancing around issues and just say it. The management is so worried about hurting someone's feelings, they tip toe around and important information is missed or not clearly communicated because they are afraid some drama will come out of it.

advice_to_mgmt: Keep on doing what you're doing! Hire people who are smart thinkers, not necessarily the experts.

pros: Awesome team of co-founders/people. Great company. I'll be loyal forever! :)

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for
pros:
Thumbtack is amazing. The culture is extremely open and trusting. Everyone has a manager, but they are very non-interfering. Thumbtack hires extremely intelligent individuals who are capable of getting whatever tasks assigned to them done. Therefore, managers aren't micro-managing and are really there to ensure your development as a person.

Everything that goes on is super transparent. Every meeting that occurs has meeting minutes that are emailed out to the entire company. Any email list or slack channel is open for anyone to join. We work in an open-floor plan, meaning that I sit two desks over from the CEO. Everyone from the CEO, to the VP of engineering, to the person you sit next to is very approachable and extremely willing to hear your thoughts about anything.

I love all of my coworkers. I would seriously be very happy to hang out with every single one of them outside of work. They are all super friendly, super smart, and super humble. They all want you to succeed on anything you are working on because we are all one team, with one mission, trying to make service professional interactions better. They are all very willing to give up their time to make sure your projects succeed.

Lastly, but not least importantly, the Thumbtack product is amazing. There was a survey done of our service professionals, asking where they would be without Thumbtack. One of the most common responses we received was "hungry." These professionals literally would not be able to find customers without Thumbtack and would not be able to afford food. I love waking up everyday and coming to work because I know I am making people's lives drastically easier and better.
cons: The only negative I can think of is that we're now getting to a size where I don't know everyone's name. That's normal at most companies, but starting off knowing everyone and suddenly not being able to anymore is a little sad for me.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work! Also, make sure as we grow, we maintain this amazing culture.

review_title: Amazing culture and opportunities for learning and growth.
pros:
Growing user base.
Excellent and supportive culture.
Transparency.
Meaningful and tangible product.
cons: Honestly, no major cons that I can think of.

pros: Thumbtack is an amazing place to work. The company's culture is the best I've seen in SF- humble and incredibly smart colleagues who I love working with, everyone really respects and likes each other, tons of opportunities to get to know everyone by sitting next to new people everyday for lunch/morning workouts/rooftop evening yoga. Thumbtack is tackling a pretty massive problem and growth has been really great to see- $130M in funding since I've joined, the team size has doubled, we've set up a new office in Salt Lake City, and we've hired a handful of really sharp senior hires to learn from.
cons: The company is still young and leaders are still learning as we grow.

review_title: Best place to work in the Bay
pros:
I've only ever worked at start-ups and, unfortunately, a big percentage of them require non-stop work with little reward, cut-throat team members and no say in major changes. Thumbtack has been a breath of fresh air in a sea of ridiculousness. Of course there are the perks that every other company here offers - home cooked meals, fancy gadgets, beautiful office, lots of fun events, but it's really the kindness and support that makes Thumbtack stand out.

It's the handwritten letter from the founders on your work anniversary. It's the encouragement to really explore what you want out of your career. It's the complete transparency around tricky situations. It's the trust given to you because you know that if Thumbtack hires you, you're opinion and expertise is respected.

It doesn't hurt that the benefits are good too - unlimited vacation (no - for real, you're encouraged to take it), good pay, work from home days and an amazing $1500 education stipend. Working here makes me feel like I'm not only investing my time in Thumbtack, but investing in my career long-term, wherever that takes me.
cons: The one similarity Thumbtack has to many start-ups is the crazy fast growth that sometimes means important decisions and processes are long over-due. Sometimes you'll hard on a project that then gets changed last minute. Or that they're so busy hiring leadership that you end up floating and without a ton of direction for stretches of time. The opportunities for career growth here at Thumbtack are unclear. I think management is open to progression (promotions/raises) in theory, but I've never seen it in practice. A lack of cost-of-living raises is also a bit of a downer.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't stress so much about making Thumbtack a fun place to work. Trust that Thumbtack itself can be enough. Office parties and boat trips and Onesie Wednesday are all great, but many of us would much rather have raises any day. Career coaching, mentors and opportunities for growth within Thumbtack stand out more than you'd think.

review_title: Very laid back company that will excel in 2015
pros: Senior management is very supportive which allows the employees to be much happier. I actually loved going to work every day.
cons: Opportunities for advancement were somewhat lacking however the culture of the company is so great that I wouldn't really consider this a negative.

review_title: Thumbtack has an excellent work environment, interesting challenges to solve, and a great culture.
pros: Thumbtack provides a wide range of perks and makes an effort to stay competitive with their salaries. They also encourage employees to always be improving themselves and to take online courses together or even teach eachother things in an informal classroom setting if they are so inclined. The culture is warm and encouraging, and it definitely inspires great work from the employees.
cons: As is often the case with smaller companies, employees are expected to learn whatever they need to learn to get the job done in the best way possible. At the time of writing there are about 80 employees in the San Francisco office, so you'll often find yourself quickly becoming the authority on a subject since no one else has done your work before. It can be stressful at times if you find yourself in over your head. There are two sides to this issue, however, since you will learn a lot by being in this position.
advice_to_mgmt: Overall the management is very strong. If you are interested, all of the meeting notes for every team in the company are published, so you can easily learn about what other teams and even what management itself is working towards. My biggest hope for management is that they can keep the recruiting bar high so that this culture is maintained in the long run despite the rapid predicted growth.

pros: Good For New Employees according to their growth and also for the growth of the Company.
cons: Interesting Projects, More Familiar, Great safety Precautions.

pros:
Before Thumbtack I was working for a larger corporation... in search to work for a smaller and more innovative company, I found Thumbtack. I have absolutely loved it here. We operate at a super fast pace, which keeps you on your toes. Thoughtfulness is also highly valued, and therefore people arent sloppy with their work. We do things with intention and it ties up into the bigger picture. Also with the growth, by default I've been able to own a substantial chunk of the business. I've thrived off of the breadth of responsibility and opportunity for broader impact.

Needless to say, the perks are great too. We have flexible time off (so there is no set bank) and we have the "typical tech start up" perks - i.e. 3 chefs.
cons: With rapid growth there are of course some growing pains. For example, we are building out a new org structure for one of the departments and the changes were not communicated to the right people at the right time. It raised questions and caused the existing team, which was very passionate about what they were doing, to question decisions. That said, I think everybody learned from the experience, and now we have a VP of HR to help with this sort of thing!

pros:
This is one of the best work environments I've ever been a part of. The team is smart and dedicated. Everyone is pulling their weight and collaboration is fun, not competitive.

Compensation is generous and the benefits are comprehensive. Family style meals a huge plus, lots of opportunities to be social with the team.
cons: The company is growing fast, and the inevitable growing pains can be a drag. Initiative is required on the employees' part that might not be required at bigger, more established companies. On the other hand, it is a big plus to have a ton of autonomy.

review_title: Rocketship startup. amazing culture. transparent and impact driven team
pros: Thumbtack has an impressive group of talented, thoughtful, fast-moving people. It's been a pleasure and absolute fire hose working here. You take on as much responsibility as you can like and in a company growing this quickly, it's endless. Love the no politics, get things done attitude. Checks the boxes on all the silicon valley startup perks.
cons: As with any startup, there's growing pains around communication and and moving too quickly. However, be proactive and bring up issues as you see them, and people really appreciate it and always (almost immediately) work to make it better.
advice_to_mgmt: Over communicate. Be clear about why decisions are made. People will find out the actual reasons - don't hide them.

pros: Exceptional people; pretty much everyone is very good at what they do. No tolerance for jerks and a nice departure from the increasingly common "brogrammer" startup culture. Lots of opportunity for trying new things and stretching yourself. Everyone really cares about what the company is trying to accomplish. Solid work/life balance - people work hard, but no one is afraid to take vacation or work from home if the cable guy's coming.
cons: The flip side of lots of independence is that there isn't the degree of mentorship or training you might find a more established company - you really have to seek it out and make it happen.

review_title: This team is awesome and the opportunity is incredible
pros:
- The team is really amazing. People are whip smart, thoughtful, and hard working while simultaneously being humble and earnest. Thumbtack optimizes its hiring process for people who are 1. humble, 2. really super smart, and 3. mission-driven. You can see the outcome of this process in the current team - I seriously feel like I learn so much from my colleagues - both on a professional and personal level - every day. I feel so lucky and blessed to be here.
- The opportunity is incredible for two reasons: 1. the enormous size of what we're going after is insane - we're trying to improve the way the entire professional services economy is run globally!! - and 2. we're helping real people in the real world. Literally every day we have service professionals write in to us and thank us for building Thumbtack - "I was down on my luck and out of work, then I found Thumbtack. Thumbtack has transformed my life. I'm now able to put food on the table for my family again, feel proud of myself again, I just bought a new pickup truck and am finally able to invest in myself..." Seriously. Every day. I can't tell you how good it feels to build a product that affects so many people in the real world so positively.
cons:
- The distance between the current product and its potential is huge - this can be frustrating. I sometimes wish we were able to move 10x faster than we currently do!
- It's a relatively young company - there is tons of room here for people of all experience levels but particularly for people who have been around the block and can contribute managerial and general company-building expertise.

pros:
- Be surrounded by incredibly sharp and driven team members. From engineering to customer operations the team is really, really strong.
- Work in a collaborative, chill atmosphere. While everyone wants to build something great, people are very relaxed at work, which fosters a friendly, warm and collaborative environment. It's driven by the personalities of the founders.
- Have a meaningful impact on people's lives. We're helping our customers accomplish some of their most important projects (e.g., putting a new roof over their home or planning their wedding). We're also helping our professionals grow their businesses and put food on the table for their families. This is really gratifying. And it's not just for people right around us in SF, but it's happening across the country.
cons: - While the team is long on smarts, it's not very experienced. For people early in their career, there's plenty of mentorship, but for those who have some experience, it's hard to find a lot of mentorship within the company. The team is actively looking to bring in more experienced team members, which should change this balance in the next few months.

pros:
Thumbtack is an ideal work environment: thoughtful and smart colleagues oriented around a massive, challenging problem that has a lot of momentum.

The culture focuses on thoughtful, data-driven decision making and dedication to the product. There are great perks like a beautiful office and fantastic chefs who cook lunch and dinner every day.
cons: Keeping up with growth and scale is not always easy. I wish there were 10 of me, and 10 of each of my colleagues, to keep up with everything.

review_title: Thumbtack is an incredible place to work in a contagious collaborative environment with very sharp people.
pros: Thumbtack has been a dream place to work at - everyone here is super smart, driven, and cares about the customers and professionals we are striving to help achieve. The startup environment is still very much alive, and there are so many perks of working here it's hard to describe - incredible breakfast/lunch/dinners, rooftop deck, a kegerator, and all the snacks you could ever want. But the backbone of the company is the incredible coworkers I'm lucky enough to work with daily.
cons: We move lightning quick - sometimes it's tough to keep track of everything happening at once, but that is also part of the experience. I will forever be a better person because of my time here.
advice_to_mgmt: I've never questioned the decisions made by everyone in senior management here. The benefits/compensation are second to none - more than I could have ever dreamed. Training is sometimes reactive, but it can be difficult to gauge what is needed ahead of time in a startup environment.

review_title: Cool place to work - hip, friendly, and lots of young, smart people.
pros: Some of the most open minded and intelligent people I've ever worked with. Great food, great culture, great overall feel - I was always excited to come to work there.
cons: Company has some growing pains and confusion on where leadership comes from.

review_title: There are so many great things about working at Thumbtack.
pros:
- The people that work here are amazing. They are smart, driven, and thoughtful, and most importantly they are people that you want to be around. Thumbtack is a community, and the culture is awesome. Please spend time with each other because they want to. For example, today our book club met (we're reading Season of the Witch--it's great) and we recently started a rock climbing group.
- The work is meaningful. Thumbtack has helped so many small business owners grow their businesses, and their stories are inspiring.
- The work is flexible. As a software engineer, I have a lot of autonomy and the freedom to work when and where I am most productive.
- The company is super transparent.
- The perks are great. A yoga instructor comes to the office and teaches a class every Thursday morning. We have an amazing chef who cooks super healthy lunch and dinner every day.
cons: - The office is a little cramped and loud right now, but that's because we're growing so much! We're moving into a new office soon.

review_title: Great place to intern and learn more about marketing services online
pros: Internship spanned across multiple areas of the start up process, given the chance to gain experience in all areas of building a site geared toward services. Daily interaction with executives, all managers are very open to answer questions and assist with any problems, completely hands on. Continuous learning environment. Gained a lot of experience in a short amount of time. Environment reminded me of Google, interns could come to work in comfortable clothing, use their own laptops, and were given free range of offices to choose the most comfortable work environment; believed that if interns were comfortable, there would be great efficiency and productivity.
cons: During my internship at Thumbtack I can honestly say there were no downsides. The executives/managers even brought in a chef to cook interns lunch and dinner so that we could continue working while getting a great meal!
advice_to_mgmt: As mentioned before, GREAT MANAGEMENT! Extremely hands on and friendly, complete transparency and trust from the CEO down to each intern.

pros: Helpful and motivated team, great perks, mission-driven,
cons: Growing pains of a fast-growing company in a competitive sector

cons: None so far. Will update if I come up with any.

pros: A company that has a family-like culture. :)
cons: Nothing to say here sorry!

pros: Cool boss and colleagues. Lots of things/to-do's to keep a hyperactive person like me busy and going. The leadership gives a good amount of trust to the rest of the people they work with. Leaders are also not afraid to go and get their hands dirty and do the work themselves.

The community in the Philippines have grown exponentially over the last several months so it's expected that there were a few "hiccups". Can't wait to see this company transform into a tech giant someday.

* very rich pay for a home-based job
* all-expense paid company dinners, trips, events, parties and TRAININGS
* promotions and career growth

We try hard to protect and preserve the culture by using Thumbtack's company values as a compass for our actions and behaviour.
cons: This is not really a con, but more of a reality check. Thumbtack is such a dynamic company that rapid changes are inevitable. People need to be as dynamic to be able to cope up with these changes. Flexibility and resilience are important attributes to have at Team Philippines.

pros: They are up to date regarding on emails, interviews, and exams. They reach out to you quickly.

pros:
I am very inspired by the vision and purpose of the founders. They are really fierce in trying to maintain a great culture despite its explosive growth.

I also love how we find ways to keep our pros and customers happy and engaged.
cons:
Most of the cons I am seeing is in it's Salt Lake City office. First off, the core leadership team are all males. While there are exceptions, most of the leaders act like fraternity leaders who are all talk and no follow-through unless threatened.

Next, it seems that everyone works in silos instead of working together. While the new org structure attempts to remove geographical boundaries and silos, it's actually created a bigger gap between the three main groups.Some groups are being ignored and are working independently because of time zone differences and because some leaders refuse to be flexible enough to either wake up early or stay up late to meet.
advice_to_mgmt:
TSL Management - please stop the drama and truly live and breathe the Thumbtack values
TSF Management - please take a second look at how TSL management practices the brand values and company culture
TPH Management - People need more assurance that they are not just contractors but genuine Thumbtack employees

review_title: Such a great place to work, even the growing pains are fun!
pros: How refreshing to be surrounded by so many smart people! Thumbtack is a place where every voice has value. No one's input is above or beneath anyone else's. As a mid-level manager, I am empowered to make the decisions I need for my team. When I request resources I am extremely well supported, and I feel my team makes valued contributions toward long-range company goals. The transparency, while at times overwhelming, is incredibly refreshing compared to other industries I've worked in.
cons: The culture of transparency contributes to information overload, which means internal communication isn't nearly as effective as it could be. I believe this will be resolved eventually but it's definitely a pain point today. Also, my compensation is lower than I would like, but I get incredible work-life balance and very interesting work to off-set that. So my salary is okay for today, but will likely be a problem for me a year from now.
advice_to_mgmt:
Our transparency is a great thing. It hurts us when the flow of information becomes a flood, and then a tsunami. Other reviewers have pointed out key decisions aren't communicated across teams. I don't think the problem is these decisions aren't communicated. I think that information is lost in the sea of updates we swim through daily. We should prioritize for this year establishing some internal communication methods to help people filter data quickly and key in on what's relevant to their team. You may need to hire someone with internal communications experience for this.

We are undergoing some growing pains; this is inherent to any company in our position in the marketplace and it's a good problem to have. But it does mean that processes and systems that got us by and were working even 3 months ago are hurting us today. Some people who've been with the company longer than I have (less than 1 year) are having trouble shifting from the mindset of fixing a problem today towards a mindset of fixing things that aren't problems yet, but will be. The first approach gets us through the next quarter, the latter sets us up for long-term success. Some training and coaching on change management for everyone in a leadership role would help. Hiring more people who are future-oriented in their decision making (as opposed to fire-fighters, focused solely on dealing with the urgent problems at hand) would also help.

review_title: Best place to work.Great team, Great mission.
pros: Thumbtack provides a Extensive range of perks and makes an effort to stay competitive with their salaries. They also encourage employees to always be improving themselves and to take online courses together or even teach eachother things in an informal classroom setting if they are so inclined. The culture is warm and encouraging, and it definitely inspires great work from the employees.
cons: With rapid growth there are of course some growing pains. For example, we are making out a new org structure for one of the departments and the changes were not communicated to the right people at the right time. It raised questions and caused the existing team, which was very passionate about what they were doing, to question decisions. That said, I think everybody learned from the experience, and now we have a VP of HR to help with this sort of thing!
advice_to_mgmt: The company is incredibly transparent but somehow key decisions aren't getting communicated across teams. Resources that are largely locked within certain areas today could be made more available to others people. Consider hiring more experienced staff across the board so there is a diminished need for everyone to be learning on the job at the same time. More experienced staff could also provide leadership and guidance that is somewhat lacking today.
